_link.title: I can describe electric current as the drift of electrons and distinguish between electron flow and conventional current

toLevel2.question: In a metal wire connected to a battery, what is electric current?
toLevel2.correctAnswer: The net flow of electric charge through the wire
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Electric current is defined as the net flow of electric charge. In metals, this flow consists of electrons moving through the conductor.
distractors: The speed at which individual electrons move
The number of protons in the wire
The temperature of the wire

toLevel2.question: What type of charge carriers move to create current in a metal wire?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: In metals, the charge carriers that move to create electric current are electrons. These are the 'free' or 'delocalised' electrons from the sea of electrons model.
distractors: Protons
Neutrons
Positive ions

toLevel2.question: What is the approximate drift velocity of electrons in a typical metal wire carrying current?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Electrons drift very slowly through metal conductors, typically at about 0.1 mm/s. This slow speed is called the drift velocity.
distractors: About 300,000 km/s (speed of light)
About 340 m/s (speed of sound)
About 100 m/s

toLevel2.question: Conventional current is defined as flowing from:
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Conventional current is defined as flowing from the positive terminal to the negative terminal. This was established before the discovery of electrons and remains the standard convention in circuit analysis.
distractors: Negative terminal to positive terminal
In both directions simultaneously
Only through the battery

toLevel2.question: In which direction do electrons actually flow in a circuit?
toLevel2.correctAnswer: From negative terminal toward positive terminal
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Electrons, being negatively charged, are repelled by the negative terminal and attracted to the positive terminal. Therefore, electron flow is from negative to positive.
distractors: From positive terminal toward negative terminal
In a circular motion within the wire
Only when the switch is turned off

toLevel2.question: Electric current in a metal is caused by the [[drift]] of electrons through the conductor.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: The slow, net movement of electrons through a conductor is called electron drift. This drift creates the electric current we measure.
distractors: vibration
spinning
collision

toLevel2.question: Conventional current flows from positive to negative, which is [[opposite]] to the direction of electron flow.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Conventional current and electron flow travel in opposite directions. Electrons move from negative to positive, while conventional current is defined as positive to negative.
distractors: identical
parallel
similar

toLevel2.question: The charge carriers that flow in a metal conductor are [[electrons]], which carry negative charge.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: In metallic conductors, the mobile charge carriers are electrons. They are free to move because they are not bound to individual atoms in the metal lattice.
distractors: protons
neutrons
ions

toLevel2.question: Electrons in a metal wire move at nearly the speed of light when current flows.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Electrons drift very slowly, at about 0.1 mm/s. While the electric field that causes them to move propagates at near light speed, the actual electron drift velocity is extremely slow.

toLevel2.question: Conventional current and electron flow travel in opposite directions in a circuit.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Conventional current flows from positive to negative, while electrons actually flow from negative to positive. These directions are opposite to each other.

toLevel3.question: Why was conventional current defined as flowing from positive to negative?
toLevel3.correctAnswer: The convention was established before electrons were discovered
toLevel3.correctExplanation: When electric current was first studied, scientists didn't know about electrons. They assumed positive charges flowed, so conventional current was defined as positive to negative. This convention persists today.
distractors: Because electrons are positively charged
Because it makes calculations easier
Because batteries were invented that way

toLevel3.question: If electrons drift at only 0.1 mm/s, why does a light bulb turn on almost instantly when a switch is closed?
toLevel3.correctAnswer: The electric field propagates through the wire at nearly the speed of light
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Although individual electrons drift slowly, the electric field that causes them to move propagates at nearly the speed of light. This field pushes on all electrons in the wire almost simultaneously.
distractors: The electrons in the bulb were already moving before the switch closed
Light bulbs store electrons that are released instantly
The drift velocity increases dramatically near light bulbs

toLevel3.question: What is the relationship between electron flow and conventional current in terms of direction?
toLevel3.correctAnswer: They flow in exactly opposite directions
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Electron flow goes from negative to positive terminal, while conventional current is defined as going from positive to negative. They are always in opposite directions.
distractors: They flow in the same direction
They flow perpendicular to each other
Their relationship depends on the circuit type

toLevel3.question: When we say current is 2 amperes flowing through a wire, we mean:
toLevel3.correctAnswer: 2 coulombs of charge pass through any cross-section of the wire each second
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Current is the rate of charge flow. A current of 2 A means that 2 coulombs of charge pass through any point in the circuit every second.
distractors: 2 electrons pass through the wire each second
Electrons are moving at 2 metres per second
The wire contains 2 coulombs of total charge

toLevel3.question: In circuit analysis, why do we continue to use conventional current rather than electron flow?
toLevel3.correctAnswer: It's the established convention and gives correct results for circuit calculations
toLevel3.correctExplanation: All circuit laws and equations work correctly using conventional current direction. Changing to electron flow would require rewriting all conventions and offer no practical benefit.
distractors: Electron flow is too complicated to calculate
Conventional current moves faster than electrons
Only some circuits use conventional current

toLevel3.question: What happens to the drift velocity of electrons if the current in a wire increases?
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Current depends on how many electrons pass a point per second. With more current, electrons must drift faster to provide the greater flow of charge.
distractors: The drift velocity decreases
The drift velocity stays the same
The drift velocity becomes zero

toLevel3.question: Even though drift velocity is slow, a light turns on instantly because the [[electric field]] travels through the wire at nearly the speed of light.
toLevel3.correctExplanation: The electric field, not the electrons themselves, propagates at nearly light speed. This field causes all electrons in the wire to start drifting almost simultaneously.
distractors: heat energy
light wave
sound wave

toLevel3.question: Circuit diagrams show [[conventional]] current direction, which flows from positive to negative.
toLevel3.correctExplanation: By convention, circuit diagrams and analysis use conventional current direction (positive to negative), not electron flow direction.
distractors: electron
reverse
alternating

toLevel3.question: The slow net movement of electrons through a conductor is called the [[drift velocity]].
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Drift velocity describes the average slow movement of electrons as they progress through the conductor, typically around 0.1 mm/s in metal wires.
distractors: terminal velocity
escape velocity
orbital velocity

toLevel3.question: If you reverse the battery terminals, both conventional current and electron flow reverse their directions.
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Reversing the battery reverses the electric field direction. This causes both electrons (actual flow) and conventional current (defined flow) to reverse directions, though they remain opposite to each other.

toLevel4.question: A wire carries a current of 3 A. If the drift velocity of electrons doubles while the wire dimensions stay the same, what happens to the current?
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Current is directly proportional to drift velocity. If drift velocity doubles while wire cross-section and electron density remain constant, twice as many electrons pass any point per second, doubling the current.
distractors: The current stays at 3 A
The current halves to 1.5 A
The current quadruples to 12 A

toLevel4.question: In a circuit with a 6 V battery, electrons are repelled from the negative terminal. In which direction does an ammeter show current flowing?
toLevel4.correctAnswer: From the positive terminal, through the external circuit, to the negative terminal
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Ammeters display conventional current, which flows from positive to negative through the external circuit. This is opposite to the actual electron flow direction.
distractors: From negative terminal to positive terminal
In whichever direction has lower resistance
The ammeter cannot determine direction

toLevel4.question: Two identical wires carry the same current. Wire A has twice the cross-sectional area of Wire B. How do their electron drift velocities compare?
toLevel4.correctAnswer: Wire A has half the drift velocity of Wire B
toLevel4.correctExplanation: For the same current, a larger cross-sectional area means more electrons are available to carry the charge. Therefore, each electron needs to drift more slowly to maintain the same total current.
distractors: Wire A has twice the drift velocity of Wire B
Both wires have the same drift velocity
Wire A has four times the drift velocity of Wire B

toLevel4.question: A student measures 2 A of conventional current flowing into a resistor. How would you describe the electron flow?
toLevel4.correctAnswer: 2 A worth of electrons flowing out of the resistor in the opposite direction
toLevel4.correctExplanation: The magnitude of current is the same whether described as conventional current or electron flow. If 2 A of conventional current flows in, 2 A of electron flow goes out (opposite direction).
distractors: 2 A of electrons flowing into the resistor in the same direction
More than 2 A of electrons due to resistance
No electrons flow through resistors

toLevel4.question: If 10 coulombs of charge pass through a wire in 5 seconds, what is the drift of electrons in terms of conventional current?
toLevel4.correctAnswer: 2 A of conventional current flows in the opposite direction to electron movement
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Current = Q/t = 10 C ÷ 5 s = 2 A. Conventional current is 2 A flowing opposite to the direction the electrons are actually moving.
distractors: 2 A of conventional current flows in the same direction as electrons
50 A of conventional current
0.5 A of conventional current

toLevel4.question: Why doesn't the slow drift velocity of electrons cause a delay in electrical signals?
toLevel4.correctAnswer: The electromagnetic signal propagates independently of electron drift velocity
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Electrical signals are carried by electromagnetic fields that travel at nearly the speed of light, not by the physical movement of individual electrons. The signal doesn't wait for electrons to drift.
distractors: Electrons speed up dramatically when carrying signals
Only protons carry electrical signals
The wire stores signals until electrons arrive

toLevel4.question: An electron in a wire has a drift velocity of 0.2 mm/s toward the positive terminal. How would you describe this in terms of conventional current?
toLevel4.correctAnswer: Conventional current flows at the same rate but toward the negative terminal
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Conventional current is defined as flowing from positive to negative. Since electrons flow toward positive, conventional current flows in the opposite direction (toward negative) at the equivalent rate.
distractors: Conventional current flows at 0.2 mm/s toward the positive terminal
Conventional current is twice the electron drift velocity
There is no conventional current if electrons are drifting

toLevel4.question: When current increases in a wire of fixed dimensions, the [[drift velocity]] of electrons must increase proportionally.
toLevel4.correctExplanation: For a wire with constant dimensions and electron density, the only way to increase current is to increase how fast the electrons drift through the conductor.
distractors: mass
charge
temperature

toLevel4.question: The direction shown on a circuit diagram's current arrow represents [[conventional]] current, not electron flow.
toLevel4.correctExplanation: By standard convention, current arrows on circuit diagrams show conventional current direction (positive to negative), which is opposite to the actual direction electrons move.
distractors: electron
reverse
alternating

toLevel4.question: In a thicker wire carrying the same current, electrons drift [[slower]] because more electrons share the job of carrying charge.
toLevel4.correctExplanation: A thicker wire has more free electrons in any cross-section. For the same current, these electrons don't need to move as fast because there are more of them contributing to the total charge flow.
distractors: faster
backwards
randomly

toLevel5.question: A copper wire and an aluminium wire of identical dimensions carry the same current. Copper has more free electrons per unit volume than aluminium. Which statement is correct?
toLevel5.correctAnswer: Electrons drift faster in the aluminium wire
toLevel5.correctExplanation: With fewer free electrons per unit volume in aluminium, each electron must drift faster to achieve the same total current as the copper wire with its higher electron density.
distractors: Electrons drift faster in the copper wire
Drift velocities are identical in both wires
Electron drift is independent of material properties

toLevel5.question: A student argues that since conventional current is 'not real' we should stop using it. Evaluate this argument.
toLevel5.correctAnswer: The argument is flawed because conventional current is a useful model that gives correct predictions for circuit behaviour
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Conventional current is a valid convention that works perfectly for circuit analysis. All equations and laws give correct results regardless of which direction we define as positive. The 'reality' of electron flow doesn't invalidate the usefulness of conventional current.
distractors: The argument is correct and we should switch to electron flow for accuracy
The argument is correct because only electron flow can predict circuit behaviour
The argument depends on whether AC or DC current is being used

toLevel5.question: In a semiconductor, both electrons and positive 'holes' can carry current. How does this affect the relationship between conventional current and actual charge movement?
toLevel5.correctAnswer: Conventional current direction matches hole movement but opposes electron movement
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Holes (positive charge carriers) move in the same direction as conventional current. Electrons move opposite to conventional current. In semiconductors, both contribute to total current.
distractors: Conventional current matches both electron and hole movement
Conventional current opposes both electron and hole movement
Semiconductors cannot have conventional current defined

toLevel5.question: A wire carries 5 A of current. The cross-sectional area is halved while maintaining the same current. Analyse what happens to the drift velocity and why.
toLevel5.correctAnswer: Drift velocity doubles because fewer electrons must move faster to maintain the same charge flow rate
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Halving the cross-section halves the number of electrons in any slice of wire. To maintain 5 A (same charge per second), each remaining electron must drift twice as fast.
distractors: Drift velocity halves because the wire is more conductive
Drift velocity stays the same because current is unchanged
Drift velocity quadruples due to increased resistance

toLevel5.question: Compare the time for an electron to drift through a 1-metre wire versus the time for the effect of closing a switch to reach a bulb 1 metre away. What is the ratio?
toLevel5.correctAnswer: The electron takes millions of times longer than the signal
toLevel5.correctExplanation: At 0.1 mm/s, an electron takes about 10,000 seconds to drift 1 m. The electromagnetic signal travels at ~3×10⁸ m/s, taking ~3 nanoseconds. The ratio is roughly 10¹² (trillions of times longer for the electron).
distractors: Both take approximately the same time
The electron is about 100 times faster
The electron takes about 10 times longer

toLevel5.question: A circuit has a junction where wire A splits into wires B and C. If conventional current of 6 A flows into the junction, and electron flow in wire B is equivalent to 2 A, what is the electron flow in wire C?
toLevel5.correctAnswer: Electron flow equivalent to 4 A, in the direction opposite to conventional current in C
toLevel5.correctExplanation: By Kirchhoff's current law, currents must sum at a junction: 6 A = 2 A + 4 A. Wire C carries the remaining 4 A. Electron flow in each wire is opposite to the conventional current direction.
distractors: 4 A electron flow in the same direction as conventional current
8 A electron flow due to conservation of energy
12 A electron flow because currents add at junctions

toLevel5.question: Analyse why the distinction between conventional current and electron flow matters most when studying the Hall effect or electromagnetic force on moving charges.
toLevel5.correctAnswer: Because the force direction depends on the actual sign and motion direction of the charge carriers
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Magnetic forces on moving charges depend on both the charge sign and velocity direction. Using conventional current (positive charges moving one way) gives opposite force direction to electron flow (negative charges moving the other way). The Hall effect reveals which is actually occurring.
distractors: Because conventional current moves faster in magnetic fields
Because electrons stop moving in magnetic fields
The distinction never matters for any physical phenomenon

toLevel5.question: In an electrolyte solution, both positive and negative ions move to carry current. Evaluate how this differs from metallic conduction.
toLevel5.correctAnswer: Both types of ions move in opposite directions, but both contribute to conventional current in the same direction
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Positive ions move with conventional current direction; negative ions move against it. But since negative charges moving opposite to conventional current contribute positive conventional current, both add to the total current.
distractors: Only positive ions can carry current in electrolytes
The ions cancel each other's contribution to current
Conventional current cannot be defined for electrolytes

toLevel5.question: In the Hall effect, the direction of charge deflection reveals whether current is carried by positive or [[negative]] charge carriers.
toLevel5.correctExplanation: The Hall effect can distinguish between positive and negative charge carriers because the magnetic force direction depends on the actual charge sign. This helped confirm that electrons (negative) carry current in metals.
distractors: neutral
stationary
massive

toLevel5.question: For the same current in a thinner wire, drift velocity [[increases]] to compensate for fewer available charge carriers per cross-section.
toLevel5.correctExplanation: With fewer electrons in a smaller cross-section, each electron must move faster to maintain the same total charge flow per second (current). Drift velocity is inversely proportional to cross-sectional area for constant current.
distractors: decreases
oscillates
reverses
